newsitem.title: CHINA: Motorola China 95 output worth $1 bln-paper.
newsitem.headline: Motorola China 95 output worth $1 bln-paper.

text.p: Motorola Inc's production in China was worth almost $1 billion in 1995 and exports from the U.S. electronics giant's Chinese operations were booming, the International Business Times said on Saturday.
The total value of production by Motorola's China subsidiary hit 8.2 billion yuan ($988 million) last year, the newspaper said. It gave no comparative figure.
Motorola, which has vowed to invest $1.2 billion in China, Taiwan and Hong Kong between 1988 and 2000, was finding success in China's growing communications market, it said.
The firm's China operations are based in the northeastern port city of Tianjin, where it has a large electronics factory producing pagers for the domestic market and parts for export.
Motorola executives have said that more than 40 million Chinese will be using pagers by the end of 1996, making the nation the world's biggest pager market.
Mobile phone sales are also reported to be booming as newly affluent urban residents seek ways to sidestep the congested land-line telephone system.
Motorola has declined to give details of its market share or even to say how many people in China owned a Motorola phone.
Finland's Nokia, one of Motorola's main competitors in China, was planning to strengthen cooperation with Chinese telecommunications partners, Xinhua news agency said in a separate report.
China already accounted for about 10 percent of Nokia's worldwide mobile phone sales of $3.7 billion, the agency quoted Nokia officials as saying. It gave no details.
